DEMAND – Children in Afterschool
Afterschool program participation in Allegheney County

column 1:
Card 1 Info

New - Card 2
New – Card 2
column 2:
In 2014, 28% of Allegheney County’s children participate in an afterschool program.

Average time per week children spend in an afterschool program

For the purposes of this study, timing was limited to 15 hours per week in afterschool care, reflecting the hours of 3 to 6 p.m.
Children in an afterschool program, by gender

Average weekly cost of afterschool programs
The average weekly cost only includes parents who report that they pay a fee for their child’s afterschool program.

Most families piece together a variety of afterschool solutions, with 61% of Allegheney County’s K-12 children spending some portion of the hours after school in the care of a parent or guardian. Other afterschool arrangements include traditional child care centers (14%); sibling care (17%); and non-parental adult care, such as a grandparent or neighbor (35%). 

DEMAND – Unmet Demand for Afterschool Programs

Children who would participate if an afterschool program were available
In 2014, 70% of Allegheney County’s children would participate in an afterschool program if one were available.

Children unsupervised after school

In 2014, 18% of Allegheney County’s children are alone and unsupervised between the hours of 3 and 6 p.m. 

Average time per week children spend alone & unsupervised after school
For the purposes of this study, timing was limited to 15 hours per week, reflecting the hours of 3 to 6 p.m.
What barriers to afterschool program enrollment are families facing?

After lack of need, the predominant challenges parents face enrolling their child in an afterschool program include: 
Lack of a safe way for child to get to and come home from afterschool programs
Preference for alternative activities


BENEFITS – Parent Satisfaction with Afterschool Programs
Parents satisfied with their child’s afterschool program
In 2014, 92% of Allegheney County’s parents are satisfied with their child’s afterschool program.
Top 3 factors in parents’ selection of an afterschool program

Is a safe haven
The hours meet my needs
My child enjoys the program

Top 3 activities/services offered by afterschool programs
Opportunities for physical activity
Academic programs/clubs
STEM

Parents satisfied with the safe environment of their child’s afterschool program
Parents satisfied with the quality of care in their child’s afterschool program
Most common afterschool program providers

1. Afterschool program run by public school
2. Boys & Girls Club afterschool program
3. YMCA afterschool program

of afterschool programs are located in a public school building 


SUPPORT – Public Support for Afterschool Programs
Parents agree that afterschool programs excite children about learning
Parents agree that afterschool programs help children gain workforce skills
66% parents agree that afterschool programs can help children gain workforce skills such as teamwork, leadership and critical thinking.
Parents agree that afterschool programs reduce the likelihood that youth will engage in risky behaviors
72% parents agree that afterschool programs can help reduce the likelihood that youth will engage in risky behaviors, such as commit a crime, abuse drugs or engage in sexual activity.
of parents agree that afterschool programs help give working parents peace of mind about their children when they are at work.
of parents support public funding for afterschool programs, while just 26% report receiving government assistance with the cost of afterschool.

In Allegheney County, 127 households and 549 children were screened for this study. According to the Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics data for 2011-2012, the total school enrollment in is 188,023, which is the foundation for all statewide projections in Allegheney County After 3PM.
